title: @Jaredan: PLEASE, for the love of lore
body:
Give us a map.

Please.

Just scrawl something on a napkin. It doesn't matter. Just show us something. And if you can't, for Christ's sake tell us why. Why has it been nearly a year without any sort of foundational background on the retconned Runeterra? What even is Runeterra now? Is there even such a place with that name anymore? I don't know. Do you?

Until you release this kind of basic info, everything you do is quite literally meaningless. You need some kind of foundation to tie everything together, and right now that foundation is nonexistent.

So please, please, please... give us a map. It really is the least you can do.

I believe I have information about this issue, however I can't remember in which Jaredan's comment I've read this: They want to release a map, however, they can't release it, unless they plan out every consequence of geographical positions of important locations - they say they want the action to govern the position of locations. Otherwise, as they say, the action will be "restricted" by a map that has been randomly made. They don't want to get an amazing idea for an event or something, then suddenly discover that they can't make it because the map doesn't allow that.

However, I find this to be a bit silly. Then a map will never be made, because they'll always need to make an infinite number of events before they could make a map.

Another thing came to my mind, and I think *this* is one of the biggest problems the Retcon has made: without the IoW, Runeterra is just another generic fantasy land. There's nothing characteristic about it; for example, Kindred could as well be from another fantasy world. Runeterra has no core identity, and that can't be made by stitching together some random stories that might be well writen, but have no meaning one in relation to the other.

I can understand being restricted.  With a map you have a clear guideline of what can and  what cannot, which can either be frustrating for creativity or help jumpstart the hell out of it.  But that varies from person to person and Riot has multiple people working on a lore team.

It's possible they have a psuedo-map drawn on a whiteboard in a meeting room somewhere, filling in the spots during meetings and constantly changing a few things.  

The biggest problem I can see in the lore is where its direction is.  The champions they've released so far have showcased the mythical side of Runeterra (with the exception of Ekko) which leads to stories within that world.  Folklore builds culture, culture breeds character in others.  

It's clear they've already scrapped the old map, Ekko's comic makes me think of that.  The old map had Piltover and Zaun separated by a large body of water that led out to the sea.  Ekko's comic had a Piltoverian kill his best friend, a high classed Piltoverian.  Now why would a high class piltoverian go all the way over to Zaun?  Crossing a large body of water for what exactly?  Perhaps the large body of water doesn't exist anymore, where now the parts that separate Zaun and Piltover are no longer just scientific beliefs, but a social standing?

Piltover and Zaun are maybe the same city, but different parts.  Though I'm not sure how people would take that idea.

Regardless of what progress they have or haven't made, what is stopping them from sharing that whiteboard map? Or some kind of inkling of what this setting is supposed to be? The cloak and dagger secrecy behind the retcon is nearly as infuriating as the lack of content. The apparent lack of direction is, I would argue, a direct result of the lack of foundation, which is itself a result of that inexplicable secrecy.

Incidentally, in Ekko's comic, he mentions the "bridge route" -- it could be that Piltover and Zaun are still separated by water, but now it's in the smaller form of a simple river, with both cities connected by bridges. _AND HEY_, maybe Jaredan could give us a quick 2-minute napkin sketch to answer that mystery, eh? This is a tad dramatic. Having no drawn map does not inherently devalue every other bit of lore that the release. There are good works that don't have an explicitly drawn map per se.

You're correct, but perhaps I didn't make my point clear. It's not the lack of a map, it's the lack of foundation. There is very, very little that ties the disparate pieces of lore that they release together. If someone said that Ekko's comic (using that as an example since it's popular) was actually a teaser for a brand new series that had nothing to do with Legend League, there's nothing you can point to in the comic that would refute that claim save for just two proper nouns ("Zaun" and "Piltie"), which themselves are so ill-defined as to be meaningless. Even the Bilgewater event, the most substantial lore release since the retcon (aside from relaunched Sion), was restricted to just one city which we didn't get a decent look at (I would say it was focused more on the characters, which is what we do not need right now).

A map would be an excellent step towards rectifying this. Aside from that, they could also release city-state lore pieces; little bits of prose that describe what it's like living in certain areas of Runeterra, either from a third-person perspective or the perspective of a regular (non-champion) citizen. The point is, we need to define the setting properly.
